constructor.details: Initializes the {EIP712} domain separator using the `name` parameter, and setting `version` to `"1"`. It's a good idea to use the same `name` that is defined as the ERC20 token name.

typeDescriptions.typeString: literal_string "Permit(address owner,address spender,uint256 value,uint256 nonce,uint256 deadline)"

arguments.value: Permit(address owner,address spender,uint256 value,uint256 nonce,uint256 deadline)

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "Permit(address owner,address spender,uint256 value,uint256 nonce,uint256 deadline)"

documentation.text:
@dev Initializes the {EIP712} domain separator using the `name` parameter, and setting `version` to `"1"`.
 It's a good idea to use the same `name` that is defined as the ERC20 token name.

typeDescriptions.typeString: function (struct Counters.Counter storage pointer) view returns (uint256)
function (struct Counters.Counter storage pointer) view returns (uint256)

documentation.text:
@dev "Consume a nonce": return the current value and increment.
 _Available since v4.1._

@dev Implementation of the ERC20 Permit extension allowing approvals to be made via signatures, as defined in
 https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-2612[EIP-2612].
 Adds the {permit} method, which can be used to change an account's ERC20 allowance (see {IERC20-allowance}) by
 presenting a message signed by the account. By not relying on `{IERC20-approve}`, the token holder account doesn't
 need to send a transaction, and thus is not required to hold Ether at all.
 _Available since v3.4._
